repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Minas Gerais Municipal Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated as satisfactory,
            with likely sustainability, though only modest institutional
            development impacts. Lessons point at the importance of
            strong, stable relationships between the Bank, and Borrower,
            a problem issue which in this case, can be attributed to
            early changes in the implementing unit's leadership, as
            well as shifting government priorities. Likewise, successive
            changes in Bank supervision leadership, also meant forging
            new relationships, and accommodating to management styles,
            endangering project success, which could have adversely
            impacted project outcomes, despite a sound project
            preparation. Additionally, while the project included
            relevant indicators, it did not incorporate easy to measure
            key performance indicators, that could have guided the
            decision-making process during implementation, and, this
            factor highlights in turn the need to have in place a good
            project management information system, prior to project
            effectiveness. Moreover, Bank supervision teams should
            include members with sectoral experience, in water supply
            and sanitation projects in this case, a coordination that
            would have ensured not only the quality of infrastructure
            investments, but enhanced supervision as well. It is finally
            suggested that focusing on a few, strategic municipalities
            for institutional development, may be the approach for
            including such objectives in municipal development funds
            projects, as well as the use of matching grants, as opposed
            to loans.

5079479.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Financial and private sector development,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Minas Gerais Municipal Management
            and Environmental Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to:
            (a) strengthen municipal financial management in support of
            the recent decentralization reforms, through technical
            assistance to increase own-resource mobilization, and
            training and incentives for efficient allocation of
            resources for both current expenditure and capital
            investment; and (b) improve environmental management in the
            State, through development of a coherent State strategy for
            local provision of water and sewerage services, investment
            in priority basic sanitation infrastructure, and provision
            of water and sewerage services, investment in priority basic
            sanitation infrastructure, and provision of technical
            assistance and training for municipal administrations in
            environmental management.  In addition, the project aims to
            begin mobilizing private resources for municipal service
            provision, test cooperative regional service provision in
            small, institutionally weaker municipalities and initiate
            transfer of municipal management skills to the
            less-developed North of the State. The project consists of
            five components:  (a) an institutional development component
            to upgrade municipal financial administration and improve
            municipal management and environmental planning; (b) an
            environmental infrastructure component to upgrade and
            improve basic sanitation and related services, primarily
            water, sewerage, drainage, solid waste, street paving and
            lighting in the State's municipalities; (c) small pilot
            programs to test private sector provision of municipal
            services, and regional cooperative investments in rural
            Northern municipalities; and (d) and (e) two studies
            focusing on:  the development of a State-wide strategy for
            local provision of water and sewerage services; and
            medium-term options for municipal infrastructure finance.

Brazil - Minas Gerais Municipal Management
